title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate of 45 percent. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry is the largest sector, followed by construction and retail trade. The number of businesses owned by these groups increased by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997. The number of businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives grew significantly from 1992 to 1997, with their gross receipts also showing substantial growth. The Small Business Development Center program proved to be cost-effective, generating additional tax revenues that far exceeded the program's cost to the Federal Government. Small businesses owned by these groups receiving services under the program are expected to have a higher survival rate. The Act aims to stimulate and foster economic development on Indian lands by providing business counseling and technical assistance to tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Increased counseling has been shown to reduce default rates associated with lending programs. The goal is to create new small businesses and expand existing ones owned by these groups. The Act aims to stimulate economic development on Indian lands by providing business counseling and technical assistance to tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. It seeks advice from Tribal Councils on where assistance is needed and ensures full access to existing business counseling programs. The Act provides small business development center assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians to stimulate economic development on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible states to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to provide a grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible states with a population of at least 1 percent Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Grant applicants must submit a detailed application outlining their goals and objectives for the services to be provided using the grant. The grant applicants must outline objectives for the services to be provided, including the capability to train a representative number of Indian tribe members, the location of the proposed Small Business Development Center site, the required grant funding, and consultation with local Tribal Councils. The grant applicants must comply with all requirements of the section, with a maximum grant amount of $300,000 per fiscal year. The Administration will issue final regulations after consultation with the recognized Association to implement the grant program. The Administration will issue final regulations to establish standards for educational, technical, and support services provided by Small Business Development Centers receiving assistance. This includes standards for work plans that may be required. Definitions for Indian lands are also provided in this section. Definitions for Indian lands and Indian tribe are provided in this section, with specific meanings outlined for each term. The term 'tribe' refers to any organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States and the Metlakatla Indian Community eligible for services provided by the Secretary of the Interior. 'Indian tribe member' is defined as a member of an Indian tribe excluding Alaska Natives. 'Alaska Native' is defined as per the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual who is a US citizen and a descendant of the aboriginal people who occupied Hawaii before 1778. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. In section 4(l) of the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act, there is an authorization of $7,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2008. Funding under this paragraph is in addition to program limitations specified in paragraph (4) and can only be used with appropriated amounts in advance. The administration can only carry out the paragraph with appropriated amounts specifically designated for it. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians.
